comments.commentBody:
A kazoo concert in Carnegie Hall does not make another one likely. I see nothing wrong with that clue.

Xenos/xenoi is mentioned in Homer often, usually to introduce the responsibilities one has towards one's "guest-friend". "Hospitality" seems a fine translation. Here's one reference with both xenoi and xenos:
http://www.snurl.com/iliadxenoi

For better or for worse, "xenia" is the concept that is invariably analyzed.
http://www.snurl.com/xeniawiki

Wouldn't correcting the wikipedia entry be more satisfying, and reach a much broader audience, than merely cataloging crossword clues? Again, your argument seems to be with common usage and a clue based on how a word is actually used is never wrong.

The buzz I hear from oil industry insiders is that the new regulations put in place as the price of ending the moratorium are so expensive that it will drive the mid-size and independent oil companies out of the Gulf of Mexico.

Devon Energy of Oklahoma City, Anadarko and Apache have been among the most daring and successful drillers in the Gulf, going where the multinationals fear to tread and finding enormous amounts of oil. Their safety record has been spotless, as well.

I know Devon Energy has recently sold their Gulf leases for fire-sale prices.

So the Obama Administration's widely promised "foot on the neck" of BP has had the ultimate result of forcing BP's most effective competitors out of the Gulf of Mexico.

Is this incompetence or collusion? Inquiring minds want to know.

TOT???

I give up. What is it? Trick Or Treat? Time Of Travel? Train Of Thought? Totally Off Topic? Hmmm...that last one...

Tough puzzle, but solvable.  I did it with paper and pencil, and so didn't have Mr. Happy Pencil to let me know some of my answers were wrongly spelled. For 4D I had CGA for Computer Generated Animation, and I spelled PIZARRO with an S instead of a Z. For the longest time I thought 35D was CRACKPOT, but I finally realized it was WHACKJOB. A couple of quibbles:  THEOPERA I didn't care for; and WETRAG for a total bore didn't seem to fit. SPLIFF is new to me. I must look it up and see what kind of joint it is. All in all, an excellent puzzle!

Hans #36.. sure that HAIR is flat? not wavy?

polly #2.. the coin flip idea is actually very interesting. blipped right over that.

- - - - - -

Here's another approach to the cookie. Combines universal values with symmetry (am stealing the solution from the classic slowest-camel puzzle).

The cookie is either chocolate (the kids love) or carob (the kids hate). 50/50 chance of each.. and the kids can't tell until they try it. Once the kids make the division they have to eat whatever it is.

This is a very dangerous development. Farmers markets are good for the small family farms because we sell directly to the consumer.  No middle man! Walmart will pay farmers less and we will have to buy extra machinery for uniform sizing and waxing. And Walmart customers will not pay the price we can get at farmers markets. It is a pure PR stunt.
Tadich Grill! Fun, Been around forever! always great seafood.

re: the kazoo-
A record of 3 performances in a half century would seem to suggest that its appearance in that venue at any given time, while not impossible, is certainly unlikely. On the other hand, it is pleasing to imagine what a treat your email must have been to the Carnegie Hall archivist.

When the Yankees pound them with hits they win. A runner in scoring position for the Yanks will score off a single just as well as a home run. Pound them into the ground,and don't worry about the homers.Hits produce homers, but going for homers doesn't produce a lot of runs. Its a game, kick their butts. Go Yanks!

Fan for life!

@6 -- I would think that if the Yankees take Game 1 then the Rangers will have to pitch Lee in Game 2 or risk falling to 0-2 before he throws.

It's possible he could then come back to pitch a Game 5 -- but even if you concede the Rangers two wins with Lee -- I think a split in the opening round puts the Yankees in a good position.

Setting the bar at needing to win the first two on the road seems overly pessimistic. If we can come into the Stadium at 1-1 we'll be in a very good position.

The reality is that AJ is most assuredly going to pitch in this round -- probably Game 4. I do expect that he'll be on a short string, however, and Girardi will pull him at the first sign of serious trouble.

Reading between the lines it sounds like Francouer is saying the Mets, particularly their hitting coach, failed to work with him properly. Just another example of a mismanaged franchise frittering away talent that often then blossoms elsewhere.

Since, as the say, a fish rots from the head, it seems the Mets are destined for mediocre performance until the Wilpons sell the franchise.

I love going to NYC in the fall. The leaves in Central Park don't turn until late in October which is when I plan on going back this year. I'm also planning on taking in a photosafari with http://www.cityphotosafari.com to see if I can get some nice pictures this time around.
SPLIFF reminded me of my college days.  The NW corner of this puzzle made me want to smoke one. Also, HONEYS for "uses cajolery on."  I guessed right, but ugh.
Almost forgot , WET RAG?  Did somebody chew up the the blanket?

"We must reprioritize spending so we can afford to invest in things like energy innovation and we need to CUT taxes in order to motivate investment."

you don't need to cut taxes to motivate investment (infact, that would probably do nothing)

there are thousands, probably tens of thousands, of scientists and engineers that would love to be researching this, but there is little funding for it. Raise taxes, an start funding the research. Markets are not going to tackle this.
I've just finished an e-mail conversation with Dr. Lewis and done a bit of reporting. A piece is coming over the weekend.

Why no mention by the NYT about Dr. Hal Lewis' resignation from the American Physical Society over its position regarding AGW. Dr. Lewis, Emeritus Professor of Physics, UN Santa Barbara referred to anthropogenic global warming a scam that with the trillions of dollars being spent by governments, has corrupted many scientists. Having reviewed the ClimateGate material, Dr, Lewis writes in his resignation letter that AGW alarmism is "the greatest and most successful pseudoscientific fraud I have seen in my long life..." More on Dr. Lewis' resignation can be found at www.wattsupwiththat.com, a great science website.
I've just finished an e-mail conversation with Dr. Lewis and done a bit of reporting. A piece is coming over the weekend.

"...I find myself stumped by the US energy department's decision to pour billions into carbon capture rather than allocate those scarce public resources to thorium — or something, anything, that will actually be (cost-effectively) useful and helpful."

— #15 Doug, Massachusetts

If you'd like to be even more stumped and stupefied, you might take a gander at a recent piece by Dr. Klaus L.E. Kaiser in the Canada Free Press ("The 'rebellion' by senior members of the Royal Society; The Carbon Cycle and Royal Society Math'). The politicized science and "fudged" numbers seem to have no end.

http://canadafreepress.com...

They are not going to do as what is being reported. Stock market is doing nicely, Job market is slowly coming back, and no one really takes the Tea Party seriously. When push comes to shove can not see serious conservative Republicans actually vote for these nutty Tea PArty individuals that do not have any experience. Democrats will do better then expected!

@dalums, TOT is the Time Out Taverne in Durham, CT, established in 1983. Over the years it has evolved into a rather upscale restaurant. The old (circa 1920) building burned in 2005, so if anyone is inclined to check the website (timeouttaverne.com) you'll see the rebuilt version.

So how come right wing extremists can win political office in the USA, while left wing extremists are left out in the cold? Oh, I forgot, billionaires like the Koch brothers fund right wing extremists.

American democracy - it was a nice idea, but too much money was at stake for our corporate masters to allow it to go on.

Hans (#35), you're working way too hard.

1. Alan does his best to cut a slice out of the cookie equal to 1/3rd (Cuts 1 & 2).

2a. If Bob wants the smaller piece, he takes it and he's out.
3a. Casey does his best to cut the remaining piece in half (Cut 3).
4a. Alan picks his favorite piece.
5a. Casey gets what's left.

2b. Otherwise, Bob does his best to cut the bigger piece in half (Cut 3).
3b. Casey picks his favorite piece.
4b. Bob picks his favorite piece.
5b. Alan gets what's left.

Here come the "Know Nothings" Mk II

Thomas Jefferson's experiment in Democracy will end before my 8 year old is able to vote because of these astroturfed Teabaggers.
The Tea Party is not a "movement". It's the conservative wing of the Republican Party. Stop treating it like it exists separated from the GOP.

We'll see how long their "influence" lasts once they have been co-opted by the republican establishment and learn to love those earmarks and committe chairmanships as much as the rest of the republicans do.
